poem:
**The Kids (Almost) in Hand**

Bitter sips behind 
closed doors, unseen – 
our children weave 
fragile threads.

No pub-clink chorus,
no eyes glazed with youth. 

We guide, 
fingers crossed over 
ever tightening nods, 

whispering tales of 
a possible "alright." 

Still,
they stir their dreams 
in measured silence.

We stand, 
guardians of 
their unsweetened nights.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The kids are all right when they don’t drink | Letters While teenagers will always want to get drunk, we as responsible adults should be doing everything in our power to prevent this (Teenagers will always get drunk – so why don’t we just serve them in pubs?, 10 September). We know that drinking as a teen alters brain structure, is damaging to the developing brain and is a predictor of lifelong issues with alcohol.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
